channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Pardoned Capitol rioter arrested for allegedly threatening to kill Hakeem Jeffries
item.description: New York State Police say the man was arrested after they received word from the FBI that that he made "threats to kill a member of Congress."
item.content:encoded:
New York State Police say the man was arrested after they received word from the FBI that that he made "threats to kill a member of Congress."

(Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)
item.dc:creator: Barbara Sprunt

item.title: Reversing peanut advice prevented tens of thousands of allergy cases, researchers say
item.description: A decade ago, research said giving young children peanut products can prevent allergies. A new study says that, 10 years later, tens of thousands of U.S. children have avoided allergies as a result.
item.content:encoded:
A decade ago, research said giving young children peanut products can prevent allergies. A new study says that, 10 years later, tens of thousands of U.S. children have avoided allergies as a result.

(Image credit: Patrick Sison)
item.dc:creator: Bill Chappell

item.title: Israel takes steps to shut down international aid groups in Gaza and the West Bank
item.description: Israel is de-registering major nongovernmental aid groups from helping people in the Palestinian territories, according to several officials with humanitarian organizations.
item.content:encoded:
Israel is de-registering major nongovernmental aid groups from helping people in the Palestinian territories, according to several officials with humanitarian organizations.

(Image credit: Jehad Alshrafi)
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf

item.title: 5 things to know about Sanae Takaichi, Japan's first female prime minister
item.description: Japan ranks low in gender equality among developed nations. The first woman to lead the country is an ultraconservative who cites Margaret Thatcher as a role model. She also loves heavy metal.
item.content:encoded:
Japan ranks low in gender equality among developed nations. The first woman to lead the country is an ultraconservative who cites Margaret Thatcher as a role model. She also loves heavy metal.

(Image credit: Kim Kyung-Hoon)
item.dc:creator: Rachel Treisman

item.title: Books about race and gender to be returned to school libraries on some military bases
item.description: The order is to be implemented at school libraries on military bases in Kentucky, Virginia, Italy and Japan. Students and their families claimed their First Amendment rights had been violated when officials removed the books to comply with President Trump's executive orders.
item.content:encoded: The order is to be implemented at school libraries on military bases in Kentucky, Virginia, Italy and Japan. Students and their families claimed their First Amendment rights had been violated when officials removed the books to comply with President Trump's executive orders.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Blair

item.title: Tech CEOs say the era of 'code by AI' is here. Some software engineers are skeptical
item.description: While AI is increasingly used to write code, every line is still reviewed by humans. Some engineers complain about having to clean up AI-generated code.
item.content:encoded: While AI is increasingly used to write code, every line is still reviewed by humans. Some engineers complain about having to clean up AI-generated code.
item.dc:creator: Huo Jingnan

item.title: Some ant architects design a colony to cut the risk of disease. Humans, take note!
item.description: One kind of tiny ant can serve as a monumental example for how to keep members of a community safe from pathogens. A new study shows how they do it.
item.content:encoded: One kind of tiny ant can serve as a monumental example for how to keep members of a community safe from pathogens. A new study shows how they do it.
item.dc:creator: Ari Daniel

item.title: Shutdown to impact federal workers' pay. And, tensions grow between U.S. and Colombia
item.description: Some federal employees may not receive a paycheck this Friday due to the government shutdown. And, tensions between Colombia and the U.S. continue to rise as the respective leaders clash.
item.content:encoded:
Some federal employees may not receive a paycheck this Friday due to the government shutdown. And, tensions between Colombia and the U.S. continue to rise as the respective leaders clash.

(Image credit: Alex Wong)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: Hakeem Jeffries says public pressure will force Congress to extend ACA subsidies
item.description: The Democratic House Minority Leader tells NPR Americans will pressure Congress to extend Obamacare subsidies as they realize their health care costs are going up.
item.content:encoded:
The Democratic House Minority Leader tells NPR Americans will pressure Congress to extend Obamacare subsidies as they realize their health care costs are going up.

(Image credit: J. Scott Applewhite)
item.dc:creator: Obed Manuel

item.title: A theory why the internet is going down the toilet
item.description: A new book diagnoses a sickness affecting some of America's biggest companies.
item.content:encoded: A new book diagnoses a sickness affecting some of America's biggest companies.
item.dc:creator: Greg Rosalsky
